model_output:
**Artificial Expert Systems and Their Key Components**

Expert systems, one of the early research fields in Artificial Intelligence (AI), are knowledge-intensive software that can perform tasks requiring human expertise [1]. They were first introduced around mid-1970s under the AI umbrella and quickly became an established branch of computer science due to their potential to emulate human knowledge and skill [1]. The general architecture of an expert system consists of several key components: user interface, explanation facility, working memory, inference engine, and knowledge base. The user interface serves as the communication mechanism between the user and the expert system. The explanation facility explains the reasoning of the system to a user. Working memory stores facts used by rules within the system [1]. The inference engine makes inferences based on IF-THEN rules and prioritizes satisfied rules for execution [1]. Lastly, the knowledge base contains specialized knowledge elicited from domain experts [1]. Over time, expert systems have evolved, with various implementation methods emerging. These include classical expert systems, neural expert systems, fuzzy expert systems, and rough set-based expert systems [1]. Furthermore, expert systems found application fields in engineering, chemistry, medicine, industry, among others [1]. However, the development of expert systems using deep knowledge that includes functional and causal relations is still a challenging problem [1]. References:
[1] Expert_Systems.pdf (2016)
